title-group.article-title: Improving tensile strength and moisture barrier properties of gelatin using microfibrillated cellulose

article-meta.aff: 1Cellulose and Paper Department, National Research Center, Cairo, Egypt
2Advanced Materials and Nanotechnology Group, Center of Excellence for Advanced Sciences, National Research Center, Cairo, Egypt
3Division of Materials Science, Luleå University of Technology, Sweden

author-notes.corresp: Mohammad L Hassan, Advanced Materials and Nanotechnology Group, Center of Excellence for Advanced Sciences, National Research Center, Dokki, Cairo 12622, Egypt. Email: mlhassan2004@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Microfibrillated cellulose isolated from bagasse was used to prepare novel nanocomposites using cross-linked gelatin as a biodegradable polymer matrix. Microfibrillated cellulose loadings up to 25% (weight percent) were used. The prepared nanocomposites were characterized regarding their wet and dry tensile strength, water sorption, and water vapor permeability. Nanocomposites’ surfaces were examined by scanning electron microscopy; the scanning electron microscopy images indicated homogeneous distribution of microfibrillated cellulose in the gelatin matrix. Microfibrillated cellulose improved wet and dry maximum tensile stress and modulus of cross-linked gelatin but resulted in a decrease of its strain at break. Microfibrillated cellulose did not affect the water absorption of cross-linked gelatin but significantly improved its moisture barrier property.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Film-forming natural polymers are an important class of materials, which find many applications due to their renewability, biodegradability, biocompatibility, and reasonable mechanical properties. However, some of these polymers may suffer from weak mechanical properties, moisture sensitivity, or high permeability to moisture or gases. Gelatin is a protein substance that is extracted from collagen, which exists in skin, bones, and animal tissue, by boiling them after alkali or acid pretreatment. Source, age of the animal, and type of collagen are all intrinsic factors influencing the properties of the gelatin.1 Gelatin consists mainly of glycine, hydroxyproline, and proline amino acids.2 These amino acids are bonded with hydrogen bonds so that pure gelatin films are normally brittle.3 The presence of higher levels of pyrolidines in gelatin results in the formation of stronger gels in water.4 The strength of the gelatin film is due to the presence of triple helixes. Higher triple-helix content leads to higher strength and lower the swelling property in water of the resulting film.5

Gelling properties of the gelatin can be altered by the introduction of chemical cross-links by using, for example, transglutaminase enzyme,6 carbodiimides,7 or glutaraldehyde.8 Cross-linking of gelatin enhances its rigidity and leads to an increase in the tensile strength of films and reduction in the percent elongation due to the depression of molecular mobility.9 Cross-linked gelatin has been reported for use in biomedical applications such as connective tissue, arterial wall, and artificial skin.6,10,11 Gelatin can be fabricated in many forms, for example, films,12 micro- or nanoparticles,13,14 and dense or porous hydrogels.15,16 Gelatin in the form of micro- and nanofibers can be fabricated by gel and electro-spinning techniques.17–24

Due to its film-forming and good barrier properties to oxygen, gelatin has been used in preparation of different composites and nanocomposites materials for different applications. For example, soy protein isolate/gelatin composites plasticized with glycerol were prepared by compression molding with the aim to obtain environmentally friendly materials for packaging applications.25 Montmorillonite nanoclay was dispersed in gelatin to prepare transparent gelatin-clay nanocomposite films with Young’s modulus about three times that of neat gelatin.26 Gelatin/halouronic acid nanocomposite porous scaffolds were prepared for use as a hard tissue scaffold.27,28 Chitosan and silver nanoparticles were used with gelatin to prepare nanocomposites for wound-dressing applications.29,30

Lignocellulosic materials, for example wood, agro-based fibers, and agricultural residues have been used for long time in different industries such as paper, wood, pharmaceuticals, wood, food, packaging, composites, cellulose derivatives, etc. They have been used as green fillers in composites for different industries and applications.31,32

Cellulosic nanomaterials isolated from different lignocellulosic materials are strong candidates for different applications due to wide availability of their raw materials, biodegradability, biocompatibility, possibility of chemical modification, and high strength properties. Four nanocellulosic materials have been prepared so far, namely, cellulose nanocrystals, microfibrillated cellulose (MFC), electrospun nanofibers, and bacterial cellulose.33,34 MFC isolated from different lignocellulosic materials represents a distinctive natural nanomaterial with high reinforcing effect coupled with availability of raw materials, biodegradability and biocompatibility. Increasing number of publications emerged during the last few years concerning the isolation of MFC using different technologies and their use in advanced nanocomposites for different applications.35–37

In spite of using cellulose and cellulose derivatives with gelatin to prepare composites for different applications,38–40 little work was published regarding the use of cellulosic nanomaterials with gelatin. The only published work investigated the use of bacterial cellulose with gelatin to prepare nanocomposite films with good rehydration properties.41

In the current work, MFC isolated from bagasse fibers was used to improve wet and dry tensile strength and moisture barrier properties of cross-linked gelatin films. The effect of MFC loading on transparency and moisture sorption of gelatin films was also studied.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Bleached kraft bagasse pulp was kindly supplied by Qena Company for Pulp and Paper, Qena, Egypt. The chemical composition of bagasse was α-cellulose 70.6%, pentosans 26.8%, ash 0.82%, and degree of polymerization (DP) of 1,174. MFC was isolated from the bleached pulps as described before.42 Gelatin from bovine skin (Type B) and glutaraldehyde solution (25% in water) were purchased from Sigma and used as received.

A solution containing 2% gelatin (weight percent) was prepared by dissolving gelatin in water at 50℃; 25% of glycerin and 1.5% of glutaraldehyde (based on wt of gelatin) were added. The required amount of MFC (up to 25 wt% of gelatin) was added and the mixture was stirred for 2 h. The mixture was casted while hot and left to cool in air then dried at 40℃ in an oven with air circulation. The dried films were kept inside closed container at relative humidity of about 50% for 48 h before testing.

sec.title: Characterization of MFC and gelatin nanocomposites
sec.p: Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out using a JEOL 1230 transmission electron microscope (Jeol Instruments, Tokyo, Japan) with acceleration voltage 100 KV. A drop of fiber suspension was used on a copper grid bearing a carbon film. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed using a Jeol JXA 840A system (Jeol Instruments, Tokyo, Japan) running at 5–10 keV. Before scanning, samples were coated with gold using sputter coater system (Edwards Sputter Coater, UK).

Dry and wet tensile tests of nanocomposites films were carried out using a Lloyd universal testing machine (Lloyd Instruments, England) with a 100 N load cell. Measurements were performed with a cross-head speed of 2 mm/min at 25℃. The samples were prepared by cutting strips of the films 50 mm long and 10 mm width. The distance between jaws was 20 mm. At least five specimens have been tested and the results averaged.

Transparency of nanocomposites films was measured using a Hunterlab D25-2 color/difference meter (Hunterlab) using the same method for testing transparency of paper sheets (TAPPI T519). The opacity of nanocomposites films was first measured as the percentage of L index of reflected light from a film backed with black tile to that of reflected light when the film is backed with a standard white tile. Then, transparency was calculated as follows: Transparency(%)=1 00-%opacity.

X-ray diffractometery (XRD) was carried out using a Phillips X-ray diffractometer. The diffraction patterns of nanocomposites films were recorded using Cu Ka radiation at 40 kV and 25 mA. Crystallinity index was calculated from the X-ray diffraction patterns according to the following equation:43 CrI=(I00 2-Iam)/I00 2

In case of MFC, I002 and Iam are the intensities of the peak at 2θ angle of ∼22 and the minimum at 2θ angle of ∼18, respectively. In case of gelatin, I002 and Iam are the intensities of the peak at 2θ angle of ∼22 and minimum at 2θ angle of ∼14, respectively.

sec.title: Water vapor permeability
sec.p: Static water vapor permeability (WVP) of films was determined according to the ASTM E96-95 standard method.44 Film samples (60 cm2 each) were conditioned at 25℃ and 60% RH for 24 h and then used to hermetically cover aluminum cups containing 5 g of anhydrous calcium chloride. The WVP was evaluated from the slope of the mass gain versus time curve. The WVP value of each film was reported as the average of three values as follows: WVP(g.m-1.s-1.Pa-1)=Δm.e/[A.Δt.ΔP] where Δm is the mass increase (in grams) of the CaCl2, A is the area of the film, and Δt is the exposure time. The thickness of the film is e and ΔP is the partial water vapor pressure difference across the film specimen corresponding to 0–60% RH, i.e., 1875 Pa.

sec.title: Water absorption
sec.p: Samples were immersed in distilled water at 25 ± 2℃ for 24 h. The samples were then gently blotted with tissue paper to remove excess water on the surface and immediately weighed. The percentage increase in weight as a result of water uptake was calculated; three specimens were measured and the results averaged.

sec.title: Homogeneity and transparency of gelatin/MFC nanocomposites films
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows TEM images of MFC isolated from bagasse. The isolated nanofibers had a diameter range of 6–22 nm. In addition, microfibrillar bands with a diameter of 50–60 nm were observed. Nanocomposites films containing up to 25% of MFC showed good homogeneity of the nanofibers distribution in gelatin films. This could be attributed to the high hydrophilic and polar nature of gelatin and cellulose. Homogeneity of MFC distribution in gelatin was clear to the naked eye and also proved by SEM. Figure 2 shows SEM images of gelatin, MFC, and gelatin/MFC nanocomposite film containing 20% of MFC. The images showed homogenous surface of the gelatin/MFC nanocomposite film and no signs for MFC agglomeration in spite of the high loading used. In addition, transparency of gelatin films containing different MFC loading was measured and compared to that of neat gelatin (Figure 3). While neat gelatin film showed transparency of about 89%, the transparency of gelatin/MFC nanocomposites at the different MFC loadings ranged from 84% to 78%. The decrease in transparency of gelatin as a result of adding MFC is expected due to the much higher crystallinity of cellulose than that of gelatin. However, due to the nanosize nature of MFC, the loss of transparency of gelatin was small and ranged from 5.3% to 11.8% at the different MFC loadings. Figure 1.
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) of bagasse microfibrillated cellulose (MFC).
Figure 2.
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of (a) bagasse microfibrillated cellulose (MFC), (b) gelatin film, and (c) gelatin nanocomposites containing 20% of bagasse MFC.
Figure 3.
Transparency of gelatin nanocomposites containing bagasse microfibrillated cellulose (MFC).

sec.title: Crystallinity of gelatin/MFC nanocomposites
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows the XRD of gelatin, MFC, and nanocomposites film containing 25% MFC. Bagasse MFC showed the known XRD pattern of cellulose I, namely, peaks at 2θ angles at 15.2 and 22.4, due to reflections from 110, 1ī0, and 020 lattice planes.45 Figure 4.
X-ray diffractometery (XRD) of gelatin nanocomposites containing 25% of bagasse microfibrillated cellulose (MFC).

Crystallinity index (CrI) of bagasse MFC was 0.59 as calculated from the XRD pattern. On the other hand, gelatin showed much broader pattern with two diffraction peaks at 2θ angles of 20.5 and 7.6. The peak at 2θ around 7.6 is related to the diameter of the triple helix, and its intensity is associated with the triple-helix content of the gelatin.6 CrI of cross-linked gelatin film was 0.37.

XRD pattern of gelatin nanocomposite film containing 25% of MFC showed three diffraction peaks at 2θ angles of 22.3, 15.3, and 7.1. The first two peaks could be attributed to cellulose structure while the later one belongs to gelatin. The peak of gelatin at 20.5 was merged with that of cellulose at 2θ angle of 22.4. Due to higher crystallinity of cellulose than gelatin, the diffraction peak of cellulose at 2θ angle 22.4 was in equal intensity to that of gelatin at 7.1 although cellulose is only 25% of weight of the film. It is notable also that the diffraction peak of gelatin at 2θ angle of 7.1 was of higher intensity in case of the nanocomposites films than in case of neat cross-linked gelatin film.

sec.title: Tensile strength of gelatin/MFC nanocomposites
sec.p:
The effect of MFC on tensile strength properties (maximum tensile stress, strain at break, and Young’s modulus) of cross-linked gelatin was studied and the results are represented in Figure 5. Presence of bagasse MFC within the cross-linked gelatin did not cause a significant change in maximum tensile stress at loadings up to 10%. At higher MFC loadings, a moderate increase in maximum tensile stress took place. The maximum increase in tensile stress was about 19.7%. The increase in tensile stress indicates good dispersion and interfacial adhesion of the MFC nanofibers in gelatin films as well as formation of percolating network of nanofibers within gelatin. It should be taken into consideration that presence of the nanofibers in gelatin solution during its cross-linking is expected to reduce the extent of cross-linking between gelatin chains. The expected decrease in maximum tensile stress or Young modulus of gelatin is compensated by the strength of the nanofibers added. Sheets made from neat bagasse MFC showed maximum tensile stress of 30.6 MPa46 while that of neat gelatin film used in this study was about 20 MPa. Figure 5.
Tensile strength properties of gelatin/MFC nanocomposites.

Strain at break decreased as a result of addition of MFC to gelatin. The decrease of strain at break was about 42.7% at the highest loadings of bagasse MFC. The decrease in strain at break could be attributed to formation of network of MFC within gelatin film and the lower elasticity of MFC than that of gelatin.

Regarding the tensile modulus of the nanocomposites, no significant effect for MFC on tensile modulus was observed till 15% of bagasse MFC loading. The increase in tensile modulus at 25% of MFC loading was about 279%. It is interesting to note that gelatin/MFC nanocomposites with high MFC loadings (15% to 25%) had higher tensile modulus than that of neat gelatin used in this work and the previously reported tensile modulus (∼8.5 GPa) of MFC sheets.42

sec.title: Wet tensile strength of gelatin/MFC nanocomposites
sec.p:
Gelatin has low tensile strength properties when it is wet even if it is cross-linked. The effect of MFC on wet tensile strength of gelatin was studied and the results are presented in Figure 6. Addition of bagasse MFC to gelatin resulted in an improvement of wet tensile stress of gelatin only at high MFC loadings (≥10%). The increase in wet tensile stress at these loadings can be attributed to the formation of percolated/interconnected network of the nanofibers and the higher strength of wet MFC than gelatin. The improvement in wet tensile stress was about 173% in case of using 25% of bagasse MFC. Addition of bagasse MFC resulted in significant decrease in strain at break of wet gelatin films; the decrease was about 63.8% at the highest MFC loading. Addition of bagasse MFC to gelatin resulted in remarkable increase in its wet tensile modulus. At 25% of MFC loading, the increase in tensile modulus was about 750%. Figure 6.
Wet tensile strength properties of gelatin/MFC nanocomposites.

sec.title: Effect of MFC on WVP
sec.p: Gelatin contains hydrophilic groups that can bind to water molecules through hydrogen bridges resulting in high water adsorption and WVP of gelatin films. Chemical cross-linking can bring about a decrease in the WVP through the reduction in water diffusivity and an improvement in mechanical characteristics as a function of an increase in the cohesiveness force in polymeric matrix.9

Addition of bagasse MFC to gelatin resulted in a decrease of its WVP (Figure 7). This means that MFC acted as barrier for water vapor permeation. This could be due to the higher crystallinity of MFC than gelatin as it was shown in the XRD results above. In addition, the higher water vapor barrier property of the gelatin/MFC films can be attributed to their better-ordered intercalated structure than that of neat gelatin films.47 Figure 7.
Vapor permeability (WVP) of gelatin/microfibrillated cellulose (MFC) nanocomposites.
The decrease in WVP was significant at MFC loading up to 5% while there was no further decrease at the higher MFC loadings. The maximum decrease in WVP was 35% compared to neat gelatin film.

sec.title: Effect of MFC on water absorption of gelatin
sec.p:
Water absorption of gelatin nanocomposites was studied and the results are represented in Figure 8. Bagasse MFC resulted in a decrease in water absorption of gelatin only at MFC loadings ≥ 20%. At 25% MFC loading, the decrease in water absorption of gelatin was about 52%. The lower water absorption of gelatin nanocomposites than neat gelatin could be attributed to the higher crystallinity of MFC than that of gelatin. Dimensional stability of the gelatin/MFC film in the wet state was also noticeable compared to neat gelatin films. Figure 8.
Water absorption of gelatin/microfibrillated cellulose (MFC) nanocomposites.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: MFC isolated from bagasse can be used as reinforcing elements for improving wet and dry tensile strength properties of cross-linked gelatin without significantly affecting its transparency. The improvement of wet tensile strength properties was much more significant than that occurred in dry tensile strength properties. MFC can also reduce permeability of water vapor across gelatin film and decrease its water absorption, probably due to their higher crystallinity than gelatin.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.p: None declared.
